utterances: But I was wondering, when you started out, was this something you consciously had in mind that you were working in this tradition, Gaye?
For sure, we were working in that tradition.

I don't think we set out to be--you know, by, for, about women; but as Ann says, you know, the blues, a lot of time, you're singing about that which gives you trouble, and for women, oft times, that's men.
So our music grew out of that same spirit of the 1920s, yes, indeed.
And a lot of--we could do a whole show of nothing but 1920s songs.
Thanks a lot, Jim, and that was an unpaid announcement.
Here's an e-mail we got from Heather(ph) in Scottsdale, Arizona: "I saw this group years ago in Virginia's Bluemont Concert Series in Warrenton, Virginia.
We sat out on the town green with a picnic and a bottle of local wine while the ladies belted it out from the back of a flatbed truck on the street below.
I've watched your travels ever since.
Hearing you now is taking me back to that lazy, summer night.
Was that the time you got food poisoning, right before the show, Gaye?
So a little bit of authenticity there when you were…
One thing about this job, there is no sick leave.
Let's talk now with Heather(ph), and Heather is calling us from Anchorage, in Alaska.
And I'm a 63-year-old widow, and your song gives me hope.
Thank you so much for what you're doing.
Well, we appreciate that, thank you.
Thanks very much for the call, Heather.
Steve calling us from Liverpool, New York.
Hi, Steve, you're on the air.
Good afternoon, and good afternoon, ladies.
I have a 17-year-old and--son, 'cause all I got are boys.
This kid picked up a guitar about four years ago and just took off, and sort of made his three older brothers go, what the heck?
Mine is less about trying to encourage a kid to play the guitar because he'll do it, he does it very well, and actually, about a couple of months ago, I sent him to a B.B.
King concert over in Utica, New York, and it sort of changed the kind of music he plays.
And so now he's a believer in the blues.
My problem is, as much as I want to encourage him, how do I find the balance with trying to enlighten him that you might want to hold down another job or plan for another job along the way?
Well, you never know what life is…
